content.body: Does it make sense to nest two aside tags into one aside tag? I need to place two things one beside the other and float them so the one on the right won't go on the next row.
nessy: about the report of problems with links in the http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-html/feed.rss feed
the feed readers I've tried do handle those links as expected
e.g., if I click on the first link, it takes me to http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-html/2010Feb/0221.html
hmm, I guess those are supposed to be absolute URIs
Morning.
TheOutlawTorn: hey
nessy: I filed a systems bug for the RSS feed link problem

Is this considered correct use of the following tags:
some stuff
some stuff again
MikeSmith: excellent - wondered if there was some setup issue
thanks!
Basically I need to have a big block inside which I will position (using floats) something on the left and something besides it on the right.
I'm not sure I'm using the new tag correctly though.

nessy: it seems that many (or maybe even most) feed readers resolve those into absolute URIs, but regardless, the feed validator says relative URIs in rss <link> elements aren't valid, so we should fix it
TheOutlawTorn: is your content all <aside>s?
Everything is inside a <section> tag. The content is above the aside tags
so if the asides are stuff that you are having rendered as sidebars around the main content, then it would seem you are using it as intended
Well I'm placing a form in one and some text in the other
all sounds fine
Hm, ok.
that would all validate, as far as I can see
but you can always check at http://validator.nu/ to make sure
It validates, sure.
TheOutlawTorn: if it validates, then the question about usage is mostly a subjective judgement call
you could probably find somebody who might think the way you are using it is wrong
I see.. thanks

annevk: Doesn't that make commercial TV non-commercial?

I thought commercial TV was TV not sponsored by the government

(but the point is it is a pretty weird defenition of "non-commercial" that includes the main way that video has amde money since its inception)

s/video/TV/ maybe. Or whatever the term is for "recorder moving images"
*recorded
having different licensing terms for commercial and non-commercial use is a trap.
setting those traps is uncool
(I'm looking at you, Creative Commons.)
is quite happy to put photos under a non-nomercial CC license
argh
commercial
That wasn't even close
But I would be somewhat less happy to put them under a simply BY license
jgraham: so someone else creates a larger work that includes your photos somewhere. Then later they find they want to make some money from their work.
jgraham: so they can't presumptively
which sucks
or they need to make more money than it costs to negotiate commercial licenses, which sucks
It seems the problem is when people think CC-NC means "free but with some extra restrictions" instead of "proprietary but with some exceptions"
and you can extort them for money up to the cost of removing and replacing your photos
hsivonen: In my spoecific case it would almost always be a case of "ask, get permission"
so effectively CC-NC is an attractive nuisance
creators of larger works would be smarter to search Flickr for someone else's less good photos instead than take the risk of not being able to make money from their additive creativity
hsivonen: You would prefer things were "all rights reserved" than BY-NC
jgraham: yes
Curious.
There are many instances where you are clearly never intending to make money from a project e.g. one-off presentations at science conferences
However it is generally not worth the effort of asking for permission to use some nice pictures in those cases

Do people giving presentations at science conferences care about licenses, and not just crawl through Google Images looking for suitably amusing clipart they can grab without worrying about where it came from?
I did. I'm not sure about anyone else
it's not clear those cases would even be violations of copyright law, depending on how many people watch your talk
But I guess there is a higher-than-average chance of people doing that sort of thing abiding by the rules
jgraham: NC is basically this problem: http://www.techdirt.com/articles/20090117/0537253446.shtml
the saddest part of it is how Lessig goes on the talking circuit talking about the problems documentary makers face in this area
and then his own organization is effectively promoting the same problem
that if you later find your larger work could be used in a way you didn't plan for, you are in a permission culture hell

annevk: hmm... "fetch" works by queueing events
er, tasks
not events
forget i said events
annevk: which means you have to spin the event loop to get them
annevk: is the synchronous stuff supposed to block all tasks?
Hixie: this would be the thread to reply to on rel if you want to make your suggestion: http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-html/2010Jan/1006.html
Hixie, yes
Hixie, apart from network tasks
Hixie, network tasks are processed to figure out when the request is done
Hixie, or to do some kind of timeout fail
annevk: even network tasks relating to other things?
Hixie, or follow a redirect, etc.
annevk: e.g. does fire during a sync XHR?
Hixie, hmm no, that shouldn't happen
Hixie: or you could respond to the comments on issue 27 here: http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-html/2010Jan/1399.html
othermaciej: is there  corresponding bug?
Hixie, only network tasks of the object in question
Hixie: that issue predates the current process, and I believe there is no bug at all relating to it

othermaciej: sounds like the process is too heavy weight, then. we should just do it in the lightweight bug fashion. I'll respond to the change proposals saying that and proposing we exercise the registry.
annevk: sounds like your life would be better off if in the sync case you just did the fetch manually
annevk: rather than try to use the event loop for everything except the event loop! :-)
Hixie: sounds ok to me
and I am fine with using a bug to track the needed change if after exercising the process there's consensus that we should go with it

Lachy: if the user who publishes photos chooses to enable the feature, Flickr disables the "All sizes" button and overlays the photo with a transparent gif
as a result, browsers offer to save the transparent gif, since it's the frontmost image for any given pixel of the photo

gsnedders: what does it mean to make them "illegal"? will the required behavior for \07 change, or will it be mandatory to reject it, or will it just be "undefined"?
there's not even a surface-level ECMAScript conformance checker so it's hard to say what is illegal for the language
(I think maybe there should at least be a checker to verify that your program is correct syntax per the ECMAScript grammar, even though that wouldn't catch many other kinds of undefined constructs)
othermaciej: Per spec, "\07" does not meet the grammar, except if you allow octals (defined in appendix B). "\08" equally does not match the grammar.
The problem is the latter case
I see, so pseudo-octal is the problem?
Everything treats that as \x008
OR octal-followed by non-octal
and by "problem" I mean not part of the defined grammar and behavior not defined
The grammar uses lookaheads to forbid it
So yeah, behaviour is undefined
gsnedders: if Brendan thinks it's not used on the Web, I kinda wish he would test that with the Mozilla code before failing to spec t
Whereas if the lookaheads asserting != OctalDigit and not != DecimalDigit, it would match the spec
sends email asking when they intend to change Gecko
othermaciej, surely you could write a decent ECMAScript validator by just adding extra code to normal JS engines, which (maybe optionally) raise a warning whenever they hit spec violations?
Of course, it wouldn't be perfect, but it would catch errors that were actually hit at runtime.
AryehGregor: the word "just" in your question contains a large assumption
That it would be easy to do that?
Well, you could presumably offer to raise warnings for at least *some* conformance requirements.
Even if most would be hard to check for.
JavaScriptCore couldn't even easily be used to check the syntax level, since we support many extensions
so step 1 would be rewriting the tokenizer and parser to remove all grammar extensions
Shouldn't those extensions raise warnings as spec violations if used?
I guess it's not quite that simple.
But it's doable in principle.  Gecko is rewriting its HTML parser right now for spec compliance, right?
thinks it would be non-trivial even in Carakan without us supporting many extensions

this stuff is hairy
"I'm not so concerned about implementers, I'm concerned about people reading just HTML5 and concluding that the spec requires sniffing"
What is the danger here?
You mean, like, what could happen if an author were to somehow read that and gain that impression?
Users might decide that since the spec requires sniffing, it's safe for them to produce content that relies on sniffing
and that would harm the UAs that don't sniff
The one user doing that seems rather insignificant compared with the thousands of users who don't read the spec, but produce content that requires sniffing anyhow
if users read the spec there would be no need for sniffing
Dashiva: you could point that out in the bug
That's still one user who would benefit from the spec being clear that sniffing is not required (from which they infer that they can't rely on sniffing)
because HTTP requires UAs to adhere to the Content-Type currently
(and hence they will produce content that works in more UAs, so everyone wins)
so it's better than nothing
Philip`: UAs that don't sniff would still be in an equally bad position
They'd be in a marginally better position, and the author would be in a wider marginally better position
and the HTML5 spec is a collection of tens of thousands of things that each make the world only a tiny bit better
If the author cared about UAs that didn't sniff, he wouldn't make content that relies on sniffing
On the other hand, if he thinks that all UAs are required to sniff, then he might not care about ones that don't, as they're non-conformant in his eyes.
If he reads just HTML5 and concludes the spec requires sniffing, then he is more likely to believe there are no UAs that don't sniff
Surely not
If he cares about UAs that don't sniff, then he knows about them
That seems untrue
I care a bit about people who visit my sites in browsers I've never even heard of
and search engine crawlers I've never heard of
etc
so I want to make content that is likely to work for them, even if I don't know any details about them
and to some extent I do that based on the assumption that if a spec requires something then these unknown UAs are likely to follow it
(particularly if all desktop browser I test in follow it too)
s//s/
Philip`: But that's trivially untrue, since a large amount of tools don't use HTML parsers.
regexp ftw!
Dashiva: It's an unsafe assumption, but (in the absence of better information) it's the best assumption I can make
I have no idea how Googlebot parses HTML but I assume that if my page is valid HTML and parses correctly in desktop browsers then probably Googlebot will parse it correctly too

and I'll happily omit

and tags, and write
etc, based on that assumption
Philip`: But that changes your assumption. You aren't actually aligning with the spec, but rather with desktop browser behavior
I'm aligning with the information I have available, which consists of the spec plus observable behaviour
If they agree then I'll be reasonably confident in my assumption
But if I conclude from reading the spec that some UAs might not have that behaviour, I'll be much more cautious about assuming it

Well, the spec says UAs don't have to support text/html, so leaving out

will break a class of conforming UAs
using text/html at all will break a class of conforming UAs (regardless of tags used)
My available information also consists of knowledge that most implementors are not entirely insane, and therefore will attempt to support text/html
Equally, most implementors are not entirely insane, and will sniff as required
maybe they'll sniff but not exactly as required

founds another crash bug in PHP over the weekend
Is crashing PHP considered to be a bug?
They are less often closed as bogus

Perl's unpack function lets you read arbitrary integers as pointers, so you can crash it trivially (unless running in a restricted-capability environment), so crashes with easy workarounds (i.e. "don't do that") aren't necessarily serious problems
but crashes in JS implementations would be much more serious because there's different expectations in the environments where they're used
but I don't know which end of the scale PHP asires to

With a really bad LFU-aging impl

I could just move over to LRU, but I don't think that's very good for what I need
e.g., given parsing a URL like '/', it may in general come up a lot, but in one file I get a thousand unqiue other items. I don't want to push that out of the cache
There's a very long tail for this from the data set I was testing with, so caching that tail doesn't gain much
What is important is you get the high priority things
Which is why I really want some sort of LFU impl
If it comes up a lot, it will always be recently used, and you'd only push it out of the cache for the duration of that one file where it's not used
Okay, then just cut things based on array_count_values(
$access)
Things that are used frequently are used recently
Philip`: It's a question of whether I want to push it out for that one file, whether I gain anything by losing that cache
Also, RAM is cheap so make the cache much bigger :-)
Philip`: PHP often runs with small memory limits
I suppose PHP isn't clever enough to have weak references

does still use an unbound (direct associative array) cache in one place, but where it grows to a certain size and stops growing due to the nature of the cache

oh great. HTML5 parsing seems to make tests from the W3C DOM Level 1 test suite fail
oops
the test had been modified from the W3C original based on an old snapshot of HTML5
now I need to change it back
so why does uncredentialled CORS still require approval to make the request?
To stop pages from arbitrarily reconfiguring the user's router on http://192.168.0.1, perhaps?
wycats: for "simple requests" it doesn't require approval to make the request, just to read the results
may be misunderstanding the question
for non-simple requests, there is at least the risk of exposing servers behind firewalls to CSRF (beyond what is possible with cross-site form submission)
othermaciej: why is approval required to read the requests?
without credentials == no CSRF, no?
othermaciej: I'm curious why there's no "safe" API to make an HTTP request that doesn't expose any security issues
wycats: you can't use CSRF to read a resource served from another server, whether with or without credentials
wycats: in intranets, there are servers where the only "credential" required to access them is being behind the firewall, which is a credential XHR can't remove
othermaciej: isn't this something UAs can handle?
and behind the firewall people can lock down the credential?
othermaciej: in practice, this means that I can't use certain public APIs until people get around to supporting CORS :/
wycats: what I'm saying is, there's servers behind firewalls containing confidential information that require no explicit credential to access
their only protection is being behind a firewall
othermaciej: right... and people can already get that info by installing a native app
the way around that is permissions
so UAs can allow the "corporate security" to disallow access
wycats: browsing to a web page in your browser should not be equivalent to installing a native app
of course not
but making an HTTP GET request is a reasonable thing to be able to do
in the vast majority of cases
and indeed the spec lets you make such a request, just not read the result unless the server opts in
othermaciej: in general, getting the results of an HTTP request is not considered a secure transaction
browsers enforce the same-origin security model and therefore have created the expectation that it is, in the browser context

"When you're using the API, it's always through an existing user in Campfire. There's no special API user. So when you use the API as "david", you get to see and work with what "david" is allowed to. Authenticating is done with an authentication token, which you'll find on the "Edit my Campfire account" screen in Campfire (click the "Reveal authentication token for API" link).

When using the authentication token, you don't need a separate password. But since Campfire uses HTTP Basic Authentication, and lots of implementations assume that you want to have a password, it's often easier just to pass in a dummy password, like X."
I think this is pretty representative
